articles.title: How top hospitality brands design their sound on purpose
articles.desc: Learn how luxury hospitality brands use strategic music curation and sonic branding to create distinctive customer experiences.
articles.alt: Luxury hospitality interior showcasing strategic sound design and music curation
articles.author: SensEar Team

structuredContent.value: Luxury and lifestyle hotels are not leaving music to chance
They treat sound as part of the brand system: researched, tested, and iterated to steer mood, memory, and spend.
Eight examples to learn from
W Hotels

Music is baked into the brand, from artist partnerships to purpose-built recording spaces like the W Sound Suite that hosts [sessions and programming](https://w-hotels.marriott.com/article/behind-the-dj-booth-with-uner/) in select properties.
Soho House

In-house music leads curate evolving playlists that mirror the look and feel of each House and its dayparts, and [distribute them across major platforms](https://www.sohohouse.com/house-notes/issue-4/dom-chung-soho-house-playlist) so members can take the sound anywhere.
The Standard Hotels

For 25 years the group has treated music as part of the stay, recently archiving that approach with ["The Standard Soundtrack"](https://www.standardhotels.com/culture/the-standard-soundtrack), a series that captures the brand's sonic point of view year by year.
Ace Hotel

A long-running music culture shows up in label collabs, live sessions, and branded streams that [extend the property vibe](https://www.cntraveler.com/stories/2015-09-10/ace-hotel-cranks-the-cool-up-to-11-with-vinyl) beyond the lobby.
Rosewood Hotels (Scarfes Bar, London)

Partnered with specialist agency Music Concierge to craft venue-specific soundtracks; Scarfes Bar is widely cited for atmosphere and live jazz programming that [anchors the bar's identity](https://www.musicconcierge.co.uk/case-study/rosewood/).
25hours Hotels
Publishes ["25hours Music DNA,"](https://open.spotify.com/playlist/2GYyzEKnynSVi5eO2f6eGL) a living playlist identity that aligns the brand's playful personality across properties.
EDITION Hotels

Maintains [branded mixes and sets (EDITION)](https://soundcloud.com/editionhotels) on official channels, reflecting a curated, contemporary point of view that tracks with the brand's cultural positioning.
Mama Shelter

Regular DJ programming and [public mixtapes (Mama Shelter)](https://www.mixcloud.com/mamashelter/playlists/mama-loves-music/) keep energy calibrated to each location's vibe while showcasing resident talent.
Two more to watch
Virgin Hotels
Runs ongoing music initiatives and publishes [official playlists (Virgin)](https://virginhotels.com/hearthis/), often tailoring selections to each city and venue.
Moxy Hotels
Uses public, [branded playlists (Moxy)](https://open.spotify.com/playlist/18e07cRHXIDILrMizuN3Ye) to express a youthful, high-energy identity that syncs with the social lobby concept.
What leaders do differently

items: They treat sound like design.
They program by context (dayparts, zones).
They combine human taste with data.
They publish and extend (playlists travel beyond the property).

structuredContent.value: How to apply this to your property

items: Define the brief.
Build the library.
Pilot and measure.
Maintain freshness.

articles.title: Three reasons to make music part of your luxury hospitality strategy
articles.desc: Why curated music is a practical way to shape how guests feel, what they remember, and how they spend.
articles.alt: Luxury hotel interior showcasing music's role in hospitality marketing strategy
articles.author: SensEar Team

structuredContent.value: Short take: curated music is a practical way to shape how guests feel, what they remember, and how they spend
Most leading luxury hotel brands treat the experience as a complete design system. Every decision is considered, from architecture to materials to the sound in each space.
Music and the guest experience
Music is a direct, cost-effective way to set mood and connect with your target audience. The right selections align with guest values, taste, and expectations.

[Slow background music](https://academic.oup.com/jcr/article-abstract/13/2/286/1846377) can lengthen dwell and lift sales in certain contexts, while [faster tempos](https://www.deepdyve.com/lp/sage/using-background-music-to-affect-the-behavior-of-supermarket-shoppers-0MSfbyjTU0) help accelerate pace when turnover is a priority. Music can also alter [perceived time](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S014829639900003X) and influence evaluations of the environment and merchandise, which is useful for [managing service flow](https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/pdf/10.1177/00222437221150930) and guest satisfaction.
Music and brand identity

Sound is part of brand memory. Consistent musical choices make a space feel on-brand and recognizable, the same way color, typography, and materials do. [Research in marketing and consumer psychology](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0001691824002105) shows that sonic branding and music cues can shape recall, perceived fit, and purchase intent. Aligning playlists with the environment and the brand's desired feel creates a [competitive edge](https://etheses.whiterose.ac.uk/id/eprint/22404/1/Wong%202018%20-%20Sound%20Branding%20-%20FINAL%20DEC%202018.pdf) that generic background music cannot match.
Music and employee productivity

Music also affects staff. [Reviews and practitioner summaries](https://hbr.org/2022/09/can-music-make-you-more-productive) suggest that background music can improve mood regulation and short-term performance on certain tasks, which is why clear listening policies and curation by daypart matter. [Industry research](https://cloudcovermusic.com/research/music-at-work-research) echoes this perception, with large shares of employees reporting they work better with appropriate music in the background.

[Music design](/sonic-identity) belongs alongside visual and olfactory design in luxury hospitality. It enhances guest experience, can support sales and revenue outcomes, and contributes to higher employee morale and productivity. [Studies in retail and restaurants](https://academic.oup.com/jcr/article-abstract/13/2/286/1846377) show that getting tempo and style right changes pace, time perception, and spend, which translates well to luxury venues when applied with care.
See what [curated music](/signature-playlists) can do for your brand. [Start here](/contact).

articles.title: How brand-fit music converts browsers into buyers
articles.desc: Evidence-based research showing how brand-aligned music increases sales by 9.1% in hospitality venues.
articles.alt: Restaurant ambiance demonstrating music's impact on customer sales and behavior
articles.author: Zoe Burnard

structuredContent.value: Sound is the fastest path to the brain, and the most underused lever in retail

Walk into any bar, hotel, or restaurant and you'll feel the space before you read a single menu line: lighting, textures, layout. Yet the signal that hits your brain first is sound - an organizer for the rest of your senses - quietly steering attention, pace, and preference ([Bitner's servicescape framework](https://www.jstor.org/stable/1252042) situates music as a core ambient cue).
Beyond background noise: the evidence for brand-fit music

Large-scale [field research](https://ideas.repec.org/p/hhs/huiwps/0121.html) finally moved this question from hunch to hard numbers. In a multi-month experiment spanning 16 high-traffic [restaurants](/music-for-restaurants-and-bars), playlists that matched the brand's personality outperformed random chart hits, lifting [revenues by ~9.1%](https://ideas.repec.org/p/hhs/huiwps/0121.html).

Earlier work already hinted that music changes shopper behavior: [slow-tempo soundtracks](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf) reduced [walking speed](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf) and increased [supermarket sales](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf). And context-congruent music can even tilt category choice; French vs. German [wine sales](https://archive.org/download/wikipedia-scholarly-sources-corpus/10.1037%252F0002-9432.71.2.245.zip/10.1037%252F0021-9010.84.2.271.pdf) swung with the nationality of the music.
What "brand-fit" actually means

[Brand fit music](/signature-playlists) behaves like your interior palette, only for the ears: it reflects values, tone-of-voice, and desired pace, so the sound "feels" unmistakably like you. Customer fit - playing only what you think guests prefer - often dissolves into a beige mix that blurs distinctiveness, especially with diverse audiences.
Why this works: multisensory science, not marketing magic

Sound doesn't operate in a silo; it cross-talks with taste, time perception, and arousal. Reviews in multisensory perception show that sonic cues can reshape [flavour experience](https://ora.ox.ac.uk/objects/uuid%3Af7af7995-1ba5-4557-bdb1-782dd9185583/download_file?safe_filename=Spence-et-al-2021-Commercializing-sonic-seasoning.pdf&type_of_work=Journal+article) ("sonic seasoning") and the overall hospitality moment. This sits squarely inside [servicescape theory](https://eclass-demo.aueb.gr/modules/document/file.php/MISC418/Lecture5_Reading_Servicescapes.pdf), where [ambient conditions](https://eclass-demo.aueb.gr/modules/document/file.php/MISC418/Lecture5_Reading_Servicescapes.pdf) (music, scent, temperature) shape both customer and staff outcomes.
What the data says in plain numbers
Brand-fit playlists beat random popular tracks, driving a [~9.1% sales lift](https://ideas.repec.org/p/hhs/huiwps/0121.html) in a real-world restaurant chain.
Blending recognizable and lesser-known tracks - so long as both fit the brand - further improves results by avoiding listener fatigue while preserving identity.

Tempo and congruency matter: [slower music](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf) can increase dwell and basket size; culturally congruent music can nudge [category selection](https://archive.org/download/wikipedia-scholarly-sources-corpus/10.1037%252F0002-9432.71.2.245.zip/10.1037%252F0021-9010.84.2.271.pdf).
The SensEar playbook: from soundcheck to sales impact
(This approach aligns with the field-experimental evidence on brand-music congruence and servicescape outcomes)
Ready to hear the difference?

If you're running a [bar](/music-for-restaurants-and-bars), [hotel](/music-for-hotels-and-resorts), or [restaurant](/music-for-restaurants-and-bars) and want measurable uplift, not just ambience, SensEar can design and operate your [brand-fit music system](/signature-playlists) end-to-end. Book a 20-minute [sound audit](/contact) and get a custom audio DNA with quick-win recommendations for your venue today.

articles.title: What exactly does a music curator do?
articles.desc: Learn how professional music curators architect brand soundtracks through strategic curation and data-driven sonic branding.
articles.alt: Professional music curator selecting tracks for bespoke venue playlists
articles.author: SensEar Team

structuredContent.value: The SensEar approach to turning brand voice into living sound
Music curators architect the soundtrack of a brand

They design purpose-built playlists and ambient soundscapes that shape emotion, guide behavior, and make spaces memorable. Unlike DJs who perform live and read a crowd in the moment, [curators work upstream](https://thearf-org-unified-admin.s3.amazonaws.com/ARF%20Councils/ARF_Creative_SonicBranding_2024_10.pdf): they translate strategy, context, and data into on-brand audio systems for retail, hospitality, offices, events, and installations.
How SensEar curates: Four pillars of planned sound
1) Constant listening with intent

Curators live at the edge of culture, mapping new releases and catalog gems across genres, regions, and moods. The goal isn't just "good music" but musical fit. Tracks whose tempo, timbre, energy, and familiarity align with the [experience you want to produce](https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/psychology/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1236006/full).

Beneath the art sits neuroscience: [peak emotional responses](https://www.brainmusic.org/MBB91%20Webpage/Blood_Zatorre_2001.pdf) to music recruit the brain's reward circuitry (ventral striatum, amygdala, OFC), which is why the right song at the right moment can feel transformative.
2) Brand & space diagnostics

Before a single track is placed, we interrogate context: vision, clientele, day-parts, acoustic constraints, and the behaviors you need (linger longer, browse deeper, buy, relax, socialize). The brief might include [speech-privacy](https://www.ioa.org.uk/system/files/proceedings/kp_roy_sound_masking_system_design_and_speech_privacy.pdf) or confidentiality needs. Cases where curators partner with [acoustic design](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2405844024130733) and [sound masking](https://cambridgesound.com/sound-masking-references/) to ensure conversations remain private while keeping the room comfortable.
3) Bespoke playlist systems, not templates
From a blank canvas, curators design adaptive playlists that express your audio identity across moments: opening calm, midday energy, golden-hour warmth, late-night minimalism. The mix calibrates:

items: [Familiar vs. discovery](https://www.frontiersin.org/journals/psychology/articles/10.3389/fpsyg.2023.1236006/full) to balance comfort with novelty.

[Tempo](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf) to nudge pace & dwell time; a [lever](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0969698912000732) repeatedly shown to shift [shopping](https://academic.oup.com/jcr/article-abstract/13/2/286/1846377) and [dining behavior](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0950329324000971).
Vocal vs. instrumental to manage cognitive load and conversation.
Representation & fairness in [artist selection](https://dl.acm.org/doi/fullHtml/10.1145/3640457.3688163), addressing known biases in music ecosystems and recommender systems.

structuredContent.value: We also consider brand personality cues. For example, sonic logos and short audio signatures can amplify perceived sincerity or ruggedness when [musical features](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0148296323005283) are congruent with brand traits.
4) Governance: keep it fresh, measured, and on-brand

Curation isn't "set and forget." SensEar runs data-driven playlisting with scheduled rotation, seasonality, event spikes, and test-and-learn loops. We tag features (tempo/energy/mode), monitor skips and staff feedback, and align with brand KPIs (dwell time, NPS, conversion). Modern sonic branding programs [measure memory](https://thearf-org-unified-admin.s3.amazonaws.com/ARF%20Councils/ARF_Creative_SonicBranding_2024_10.pdf), recognition, and emotional lift, then iterate to improve asset recall and engagement.
Why it works: the evidence behind strategic sound

Tempo steers pace & spend. [Slow-tempo music](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf) can lengthen in-store time and increase sales; similar effects appear in [restaurants](https://academic.oup.com/jcr/article-abstract/13/2/286/1846377) where slower music extends [dining duration](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0950329324000971).

Emotion is the engine. Peak musical pleasure lights up the [brain's reward network](https://www.brainmusic.org/MBB91%20Webpage/Blood_Zatorre_2001.pdf), explaining why calibrated soundscapes can reliably shift mood and memory.

From jingles to systems. Sonic branding is now measured like visual identity; [assets are tested](https://thearf-org-unified-admin.s3.amazonaws.com/ARF%20Councils/ARF_Creative_SonicBranding_2024_10.pdf), optimized, and governed for [recall and fit](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0148296323005283).

Privacy matters in real spaces. [Sound masking](https://www.ioa.org.uk/system/files/proceedings/kp_roy_sound_masking_system_design_and_speech_privacy.pdf) and [spatial design](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2405844024130733) improve speech privacy without killing ambience, which is crucial for healthcare, offices, and [premium retail](https://cambridgesound.com/sound-masking-references/).
Curators vs. DJs

DJs perform; curators pre-engineer the experience. Curators build scalable, context-aware retail soundscapes and experiential audio systems that teams can run daily; grounded in brand strategy, psychoacoustics, and [measurement](https://thearf-org-unified-admin.s3.amazonaws.com/ARF%20Councils/ARF_Creative_SonicBranding_2024_10.pdf).
Ready to hear your brand?

If you're designing a new space, refreshing an audio identity, or want measurable uplift from in-store music, SensEar can help; [strategy](https://sensear.music/sonic-identity), [curation](https://sensear.music/signature-playlists), and governance included. Let's build a sound your customers remember and your team can run every day. Get your [free sonic audit](https://sensear.music/contact) today.

structuredContent.value: How continuous music curation optimization enhances venue atmosphere with data-driven strategies.
Music is more than ambience

The right track at the right moment can reshape how a room feels. In the lobby, use calm, mid-tempo selections to ease arrivals and reduce noise fatigue ([source](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0969698923002345)). In the dining room, steady rhythmic music supports conversational comfort and smooth service pacing ([source](https://academic.oup.com/jcr/article-abstract/13/2/286/1846377)). For late sets, increase energy and tempo to keep guests engaged for longer and encourage an extra round ([source](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/1750984X.2011.631026)).
At SensEar, we design those shifts on purpose. For venues that care about guest experience and brand voice, curated music strengthens sonic identity, increases dwell time, and supports repeat visits.
Curation is a loop, not a checkbox

Great programming is never "set it and forget it." It starts with a launch and continues through measurement and refinement. We review performance regularly, remove tracks that feel tired or trigger skips, and add new material that matches your audience. Slow-paced selections can increase time on site and spending in certain contexts ([source](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf)). In restaurants, slower music has been linked with guests staying longer and ordering more, while faster tempos can speed table turnover when needed ([source](https://academic.oup.com/jcr/article-abstract/13/2/286/1846377)).
Humans in the mix

Our curators are musicians, DJs, and ethnomusicologists with backgrounds in labels, radio, classical stages, and tech. They spend time in your space to understand the flow of service and daily rhythms. We test in context: pacing a fitness studio to verify tempo curves for classes ([source](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1469029224000554)), running a full dinner service to validate energy arcs for peak hours ([source](https://academic.oup.com/jcr/article-abstract/13/2/286/1846377)), or evaluating quiet sets for spa settings to avoid listener fatigue ([source](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/1750984X.2011.631026)).
Stay current. Stay relevant.

What works today can feel dated in a few months. Culture moves and tastes shift. Matching music to context can also steer choices. For example, when background music aligns with cultural cues, guests are more likely to choose congruent products, such as French music increasing French wine selection in a retail test ([source](https://archive.org/download/wikipedia-scholarly-sources-corpus/10.1037%252F0002-9432.71.2.245.zip/10.1037%252F0021-9010.84.2.271.pdf)). Programming benefits from tracking trends and audience response in real time rather than relying only on static algorithms.
The craft and the science

Every set is shaped by feel and by data. We look at tempo, intensity, cadence, and bpm to match the arc of your environment. Music also changes how time is perceived. Retail experiments show background music can alter both perceived and actual shopping duration, which affects evaluations and spend ([source](https://rybn.org/ANTI/ADMXI/documentation/ALGORITHM_DOCUMENTATION/HARMONY_OF_THE_SPEARS/BACKGROUND_MUSIC_STUDIES/EFFECT_ON_CONSUMPTION/2000_The_Effects_of_Music_in_a_Retail_Setting_on_Real_and_Perceived_Shopping_Times.pdf)).

Fitness studios: Plan build-ups, peaks, and recovery moments. Faster tempos tend to align better as intensity rises and can improve affect and perceived exertion ([source](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1469029224000554)) ([source](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/1750984X.2011.631026)).

Restaurants and bars: Use slower tempos to lengthen stays when desired, and increase pace to support faster turns during rush periods ([source](https://academic.oup.com/jcr/article-abstract/13/2/286/1846377)).

Spas and lounges: Favor gentle entries, stable mid-sections, and unhurried fades to maintain calm without dulling the space ([source](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/1750984X.2011.631026)).

Retail and gallery spaces: Align cues across the environment. When scent and music arousal levels match, shopper evaluations improve, which shows the value of tuning the whole atmosphere, not just the playlist ([source](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022435901000422)). A public preprint is also available [here for easy access](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Jochen-Wirtz/publication/222542870_Congruency_of_Scent_and_Music_as_a_Driver_of_In-Store_Evaluations_and_Behavior/links/59f47c0a458515547c21c2be/Congruency-of-Scent-and-Music-as-a-Driver-of-In-Store-Evaluations-and-Behavior.pdf).
What you get with SensEar

items: Programming that evolves with your clientele and dayparts
Specialists who test music inside your real-world service flow
Frequent updates that keep sets fresh and culturally tuned
A balance of analytics and expert taste that outperforms one-size-fits-all music

articles.title: Building a brand people can hear
articles.desc: Strategic guide to sonic branding and audio identity development. Create memorable brand experiences through music and sound design.
articles.alt: Sonic branding strategy building brand identity through music
articles.author: SensEar Team

structuredContent.value: Strategic guide to sonic branding and audio identity development through music and sound design.
Why sound is your most underrated brand asset

Brand identity is more than visuals. It is the total set of signals that help people recognize you and trust what you deliver. That includes name, logo, typography, color, packaging, and physical spaces. But in a crowded market, consistent sound cues cut through faster, travel further, and stick longer in memory. [Sensory marketing research](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1057740811000830) shows that engaging multiple senses strengthens perception, judgment, and behavior, and sound is uniquely efficient at doing this at scale.
What a brand really is

A brand is a promise people can identify instantly and rely on consistently. Customers use brand cues to infer benefits and quality before they buy. Visual consistency matters, and color is often cited as boosting recognition, though [that specific 80 percent statistic is frequently misquoted](https://reviewinc.com/2024/08/14/color-increases-brand-recognition/) and context dependent, originally tied to [document processing rather than logos alone](https://www.insights4print.ceo/2019/02/color-increases-brand-recognition-by-80-the-real-contents-of-the-loyola-study-revealed/).
The power of sonic branding

Music and sound are immediate, emotional, and memorable. Field experiments show that background music can shape traffic flow and lift sales, especially when tempo and musical mode are intentionally selected for context, not chosen at random. For example, [research in a supermarket](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf) found that slow tempo music lengthened shopping time and increased sales volume compared to fast tempo tracks. [Interaction effects of tempo and mode](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Klemens-Knoeferle/publication/227451750_It_is_all_in_the_mix_The_interactive_effect_of_music_tempo_and_mode_on_in-store_sales/links/0a85e530360b6bd8a7000000/It-is-all-in-the-mix-The-interactive-effect-of-music-tempo-and-mode-on-in-store-sales.pdf) can also influence in-store sales outcomes, suggesting playlists should be composed with both parameters in mind for the desired behavioral effect.

Congruence matters. When the music fits the offer, people choose in line with that cue. In a [classic wine aisle study](https://archive.org/download/wikipedia-scholarly-sources-corpus/10.1037%252F0002-9432.71.2.245.zip/10.1037%252F0021-9010.84.2.271.pdf), French music increased French wine sales while German music increased German wine sales, demonstrating that culturally congruent sound nudges product choice without a single spoken word.

Sonic logos amplify this effect by giving your brand a short, distinctive audio signature that boosts recall and recognition. [Recent research](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0148296323005283) links well designed sonic logos to stronger memory and brand personality fit, including attributes like sincerity or ruggedness when the [musical features align with brand strategy](https://idj.journals.ekb.eg/article_340785_a40c2229d0f8979f8c85180171b7e998.pdf), supported by additional [branding studies](https://journal.ipb.ac.id/index.php/jcs/article/view/57484).
A practical framework for sound-first brand strategy
Use this six-step process to align sound with your brand promise and performance goals.

items:
1. Identify your priority customers and motivational triggers
Use qualitative interviews and journey mapping to uncover when and why sound will help reduce friction or heighten emotion. Anchor findings in [sensory marketing principles](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1057740811000830) so you are designing for perception and behavior, not just taste in music.

2. Define a value proposition people can hear
Translate your value proposition into sonic territories. If you stand for calm expertise, consider slower tempos and stable modes. If you stand for energetic discovery, explore higher tempos with bright timbres. [Evidence shows](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Klemens-Knoeferle/publication/227451750_It_is_all_in_the_mix_The_interactive_effect_of_music_tempo_and_mode_on_in-store_sales/links/0a85e530360b6bd8a7000000/It-is-all-in-the-mix-The-interactive-effect-of-music-tempo-and-mode-on-in-store-sales.pdf) tempo and mode influence pace and purchase behavior, so plan accordingly.

3. Assess competitor soundscapes
Audit competitors' playlists, voice and tone, and any sound logos. [Sonic branding is still under-researched](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/02650487.2023.2273075) relative to impact, which means there is room to differentiate with evidence-led craft rather than copycat playlists.

4. Design core sonic assets
Create a modular system: a primary sonic logo, mnemonic stingers, UX sounds, and environment-specific playlists. Ensure [musical features align with your brand personality](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0148296323005283) so the audio signature signals the same traits your visuals do.

5. Craft a clear, testable brand promise
Articulate how sound supports the promise. For instance, promise a calmer check-in experience in hospitality by using low-arousal tracks in lobbies and rooms. Test against behavioral KPIs like dwell time, service ratings, and repeat visit intent. [Supermarket studies](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf) demonstrate that music can measurably change pace and purchases, so treat playlists as performance media, not background filler.

6. Activation the right brand touchpoints
Prioritize high-impact touchpoints where customers can hear and feel your promise. In hospitality and retail, that includes entrances, lobbies, dining areas, fitting rooms, mobile apps, IVR systems, and short-form video. Make congruency your rule. The [wine aisle study](https://archive.org/download/wikipedia-scholarly-sources-corpus/10.1037%252F0002-9432.71.2.245.zip/10.1037%252F0021-9010.84.2.271.pdf) shows how aligning music with context quietly tilts choice in your favor.

structuredContent.value: Brand touchpoints to prioritize: the sonic experience

Sound is one of the most powerful brand touchpoints because it works instantly, sets emotional temperature, and is easy to standardize across locations and channels. When thoughtfully integrated into your brand system, your music and sonic logo do more than decorate a space. They become the voice of your brand that customers recognize before they even look up. For hospitality brands, this translates into consistent quality cues that reduce uncertainty and increase loyalty over time, supported by a growing body of work in [sensory marketing](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1057740811000830) and [sonic branding research](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1080/02650487.2023.2273075).
Ready to make your brand heard?

If you want [playlists that perform](https://sensear.music/signature-playlists), a [sound logo people remember](https://sensear.music/sonic-identity), and [audio guidelines](https://sensear.music/services) your teams can apply everywhere, SensEar can help. [Book a discovery session](https://sensear.music/contact) and we will map your [customer journey](https://sensear.music/industries), test what your audience responds to, and build a sonic branding system that lifts recognition, improves experience, and drives [measurable results](https://sensear.music/case-studies). Let's design the sound of your brand today.

articles.title: Sound strategy that sells: how background music shapes customer behavior
articles.desc: Field research reveals how strategic background music increases sales and dwell time in retail and hospitality environments.
articles.alt: Retail environment showing background music influence on shopping behavior
articles.author: Research Team

structuredContent.value: Field research reveals how strategic background music affects dwell time, pace, and spending in retail and hospitality environments.
Quick take

The right soundtrack can make people stay longer and spend more, but results depend on who is in the room and what kind of place you run. The field evidence in [the study](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0969698912000732) with real shoppers shows clear lifts in time and spending on music days, with different patterns by gender and store type.

Other research in restaurants and supermarkets finds similar effects tied to tempo and song choice ([restaurant tempo classic](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2489234); [supermarket pacing summary](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf)).
Why sound changes behavior

Store and venue cues shape feelings like pleasure and alertness, which then drive approach or avoidance behaviors such as exploring, talking to staff, or buying. This path is laid out in the well-known PAD model from environmental psychology ([overview](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022435997900166)).
What the field data actually found

items: •More time and more spend with music. In real stores, shoppers stayed longer and spent more when music played than when it was quiet ([the study](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0969698912000732)).

•Tempo steers pace. Slower tracks tend to slow movement and can lift basket size or drink orders, while faster tracks speed things up when you need quicker turns ([restaurants](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2489234); [grocery pace](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf)).

•Fit beats one-size-fits-all. Effects vary by audience and setting. A meta-view of retail music studies shows outcomes depend on execution quality and context, not just "music on" vs "off" ([meta-analysis](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0148296306000282)).

•Waiting feels shorter with the right tracks. Music that matches the setting can ease the pain of waiting and support friendlier behavior in service lines and lobbies ([waiting study PDF](https://chaireomerdesserres.hec.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/The-Impact-of-Music-on-Consumers-Reactions-to-Waiting-for-Services.pdf)).

•Different people, different reactions. In the study's two retail tests, women often favored no music or slower music, while men often favored music and quicker tempos. Short-term sales can rise even if some guests enjoy the experience less, which can hurt repeat visits later if you do not tune the mix to your audience ([the study](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0969698912000732)).

structuredContent.value: Does this apply outside retail?

Yes. Although the experiments took place in an electronics store and a supermarket, the same emotion-to-behavior path applies in many settings. Prior work shows similar music effects in restaurants and other service venues when the soundtrack fits the moment and the crowd ([restaurant tempo](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2489234); [PAD model overview](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022435997900166)).
The SensEar checklist: fast setup for retail, bars, and restaurants
Use this to test safely without hurting guest experience.

items:
Set clear goals
Retail: grow dwell and basket size, or speed quick trips.
Bars: increase orders per guest or speed table turns.
Restaurants: control seating pace and upsells without raising stress.

Choose tempo by mission
Need browsing and discovery: lean slower.
Need quick movement and faster turns: lean faster.
Always test a middle set as your control.

Match the crowd and time of day
Mornings and older or family-heavy periods: lighter, slower sets.
Evenings and younger or high-energy periods: a notch faster.
If your audience skews female, trial quieter or slower sessions. If it skews male, trial more energetic sessions. Validate with data from your own floor traffic.

Keep volume comfortable
People should talk without raising their voice. If staff say they are tired by midday, it is too loud.

Keep the style on brand
Pick songs that feel like your space. "Good fit" beats raw BPM tweaks.

Measure short and long results
Short term: sales per visitor, time on site, orders per table, queue abandonment.
Long term: customer satisfaction, reviews, repeat rate, staff feedback.

Test, then tune
Run A/B dayparts for two weeks per set.
Swap one variable at a time: tempo, volume, or playlist.
Keep the winner and retest monthly.

structuredContent.value: Sources

items: • The study with real shoppers and gender moderation in retail settings: [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0969698912000732](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0969698912000732)
• Meta-analysis of retail music effects: [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0148296306000282](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0148296306000282)
• PAD model summary in environmental psychology: [https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022435997900166](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022435997900166)
• Restaurant tempo classic: [https://www.jstor.org/stable/2489234](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2489234)

• Supermarket pacing and sales summary: [https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf](https://music2biz.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Using-Background-Music-to-Affect-the-Behavior-of-Supermarket-Shoppers.pdf)

• Music and perceived waiting time: [https://chaireomerdesserres.hec.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/The-Impact-of-Music-on-Consumers-Reactions-to-Waiting-for-Services.pdf](https://chaireomerdesserres.hec.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/The-Impact-of-Music-on-Consumers-Reactions-to-Waiting-for-Services.pdf)

articles.title: How your service environment shapes perceived wait time
articles.desc: How music and environmental design can transform the waiting experience and improve customer satisfaction.
articles.alt: Service environment design using music to improve customer waiting experience
articles.author: Research Team

structuredContent.value: How music and environmental design can transform the waiting experience and improve satisfaction.
Managing how customers feel about waiting can be as important as reducing the clock time itself
A short wait to a manager can feel long to a guest if the environment works against them.
Why waiting feels longer than it is

[Customers often overestimate how long they have waited](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Ale-Smidts/publication/247220346_Effects_of_waiting_on_the_satisfaction_with_the_service_Beyond_objective_time_measures/links/5cc83a9e4585156cd7bc091c/Effects-of-waiting-on-the-satisfaction-with-the-service-Beyond-objective-time-measures.pdf), and satisfaction drops as perceived wait length grows. Traditional fixes focus on operations that cut actual queue time, but [research shows the setting and information during the wait also shape satisfaction](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Naveen-Donthu/publication/242337184_Closing_the_gap_between_perceived_and_actual_waiting_times_in_a_call_center_Results_from_a_field_study/links/64bff61a8de7ed28bac2b9e0/Closing-the-gap-between-perceived-and-actual-waiting-times-in-a-call-center-Results-from-a-field-study-Results-from-a-field-study.pdf), sometimes more than small shifts in seconds or minutes.
How the environment shapes perception

The physical and sensory setting affects emotional, cognitive, and physiological responses that drive evaluations and behaviors. [Servicescape research ties these effects to core pleasure and arousal states](https://eclass-demo.aueb.gr/modules/document/file.php/MISC418/Lecture5_Reading_Servicescapes.pdf) that color time perception and satisfaction.
The environmental factors that matter

[Lighting, temperature, music, scent, and background noise set the sensory baseline](https://journals.itb.ac.id/index.php/ajht/article/view/25753/7113) and can shift satisfaction and perceived time in hospitality and retail settings.
[Color, furnishings, signage, and spatial layout guide flow and expectations](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0278431918310430), influencing attention and affect during waits.
Who is present matters. [The presence of staff and other guests can soften the experience](https://philpapers.org/rec/PRUCRT), and waiting with others can improve acceptability during longer waits.
How music changes perceived wait time

[Music that creates positive affect tends to shorten perceived wait](https://chaireomerdesserres.hec.ca/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/The-Impact-of-Music-on-Consumers-Reactions-to-Waiting-for-Services.pdf), while poorly matched music can lengthen it. The mechanism combines [attention capture, mood regulation, and tempo effects that influence internal timekeeping](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1071581921001749). Identifying what works for a specific segment and context requires testing and professional curation, since [responses vary by genre, volume, and tempo](https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022435997900166).
Practical steps for managers

Make ambient baselines a management priority. [Calibrate lighting, temperature, music volume, and tempo to the setting and daypart](https://journals.itb.ac.id/index.php/ajht/article/view/25753/7113), then validate with guest feedback and metrics. Understand the affective profile of the music you select for your target market, and use [playlists that align with desired mood and pace](https://sensear.music/signature-playlists) for each zone and queue type.

The right music does more than fill silence. It improves the waiting experience, reduces perceived wait time, and supports higher satisfaction. This is where [professional music curation](https://sensear.music/services) delivers measurable value in [service environments](https://sensear.music/industries).

hero.title: Understanding how it works
hero.subtitle: Answers to common questions about sound, licensing & our services.

items.question: Is it legal to play music from Spotify, YouTube, or Apple Music in my restaurant/bar/hotel?
items.answer: Typically, consumer streaming platforms (like Spotify Free/Premium, YouTube, Apple Music, etc.) are licensed only for personal use, meaning they do not cover public performance rights in a commercial setting. You'll need a business license or properly licensed service to legally play music for your patrons.

items.question: Why can't I just use my personal Spotify or Apple Music subscription?
items.answer: Personal subscriptions don't include public performance or commercial use rights. Using them in a public venue can violate copyright law and may lead to fines or legal complications. Commercial music services, by contrast, include the necessary licenses for public playback.

items.question: What is a public performance license, and why do I need it?
items.answer: A Public Performance License is an agreement that compensates artists, songwriters, and music publishers when their work is played in a public venue. You must utilize it to legally broadcast or perform music in restaurants, bars, hotels, retail stores, etc. SensEar can help you navigate or secure these licenses for peace of mind.

items.question: How long does it take to create a custom playlist?
items.answer: It varies. For a single venue with a clear music profile, it may take just a few days. For larger or multi-location clients, it can take a week or more to finalize the whole process.

items.question: Is your music fully licensed?
items.answer: Yes. All tracks are properly licensed so you can focus on running your business without any legal concerns.

items.question: Can I update the music playlists myself?
items.answer: Absolutely. Our user-friendly platform allows you to make quick changes, adjust settings, or schedule different playlists for specific times.

items.question: Do I need special equipment for playing your music playlists?
items.answer: Basic sound systems work just fine, but if you want specialized audio-visual solutions, we can provide design, purchase, and installation services. For more info see our AV Design & Integration section.

items.question: Do you offer support after setup?
items.answer: Yes. We are available for ongoing support, updates, and any adjustments you need along the way. Just send us a message and we will talk about it.

items.question: What is the difference between background music and bespoke curation?
items.answer: Background Music offers pre-curated, automated playlists for a seamless ambiance, ideal for general business needs. Bespoke Curation is a fully customized music strategy, crafted to reflect a brand's identity and create a unique, immersive experience. It is ideal for luxury venues, boutique spaces, and businesses seeking a signature sound experience.
